topic.title: Why a style guide starter for DITA
topic.abstract: DITA provides a consistent structure for content. However, to get truly consistent content out of DITA, it is necessary to use a consistent syntax within the elements that form the structure. This style guide starter provides a set of guidelines from which you can draw inspiration to define your own set of rules.

section.title: No single truth, hence a style guide starter
section.p: This guide is not trying to define the way everyone should create content.

ul.li: Improve the experience of your target audience. You don't address sports fan the same way you address bankers.
Work for your specific reuse strategies.

Support your business objectives. If you develop training material, you may need guidelines for writing learning objectives, while someone that writes maintenance guides for a nuclear power plant may be more interested in security notices.

section.p: Hence, this style guide is a starting point for teams to define their common voice.

It is ok to adapt this style guide to your preferences. It is important, however, that everyone in your team follows the same guidelines. An organization should have a single style guide to maximize collaboration, reuse and avoid departmental silos.

ul.li: Improve writers' compliance. People buy into rules when they understand their purpose. Writing in a collaborative environment and creating content for multiple contexts and media is new to most writers. Show them how most rules support reuse and business objectives.
Avoid rules perversion. Following rules blindly often leads to abberations. Applying rules to the wrong context can create problems rather than solve them.

Support maintenance. Some rules may need to change over time as the context evolves, when new media emerge, or when some publications become obsolete. It's easier to maintain a good set of rules when you remember why the rule was created in the 1st place.
